WAR CABINET 33 (39).
CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10 Downing Street, S.W. 1, on Sunday, October 1, 1939, at 12 noon.
Present:
The Right Hon. Sir Samuel Hoare, Bt., M.P., Lord Privy Seal (in the Chair).
The Right Hon. Winston S. Churchill, M.P., First Lord of the Admiralty.
The Right Hon. L. Hore-Belisha, M.P., Secretary of State for War.
The following were also present:
Sir Horace j. Wilson, Permanent Secretary to the Treasury.
Lieutenant-General Sir Ronald Adam, Bt., Deputy Chief of the Imperial General Staff.
Admiral of the Fleet Sir Dudley Pound, First Sea Lord and Chief of Naval Staff.
Air Vice-Marshal R. E. C. Peirse, Deputy Chief of the Air Staff.
Sir Orme Sargent, Assistant Under-Secretary of State, Foreign Office (Items 5-9).
Secretariat.
Major-General H. L. Ismay. Mr. F. Hemming. Mr. W. D. Wilkinson. Lieutenant-Colonel V. Dykes, R.E. Lieutenant-Colonel E. I. C. Jacob, R.E.

The Air 1. The Deputy Chief of the Air Staff reported that 5 Battles
Situation. carrying out reconnaissance in the Rheims area had been attacked (Previous by 15 Messerschmidt Fighters at 22,000 feet. Four out of the Reference: 5 Battles had been shot down, but one German fighter was known, W.M. (39) 32nd and a second believed, to have been destroyed. It was understood Conclusions, that the majority of the crews of our aircraft had escaped in their Minute l.) parachutes. Two Hudsons had been lost in a reconnaissance over Sylt the previous day. The Germans admitted the loss of 2 fighters in the action over the Heligoland Bight on the 29th, when we had lost 5 Hampdens. The French claimed to have brought down 6 Messerschmidt fighters the previous day.
In discussion, it was brought out that the balance of the losses seemed to be against us. The enemy was apparently lying in wait for our reconnaissances, and it might be necessary to use larger formations and to escort them with fighters, as did the French. Variation of the times and routes of reconnaissances was, of course, essential.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.
Naval 2. The First Lord of the Admiralty said that, if nothing
Operations. happened by 1 p.m., a whole week would have passed without a (Previous single attack on any British merchant ship. German submarines Reference: were still about, however, and anti-submarine operations were being W.M. (39) 32nd vigorously pursued. He gave details of some attacks, one of which, Conclusions, south-east of Plymouth, was most promising. The Germans had Minute 2.) now announced in a broadcast that they would begin unrestricted submarine waff are against our shipping, since, as they alleged, our merchantmen were now armed and had fired on their submarines. The allegation was untrue, but the Admiralty had thought it right to send a warning message to all shipping that unrestricted attack should now be anticipated.
No sign had been found of the reported concentration of German vessels in the Southern Atlantic.
Mention was made of a German submarine reported to have been seen in Donegal Bay, and it was suggested that the attention of the Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs should be drawn to this report, and that, if it were substantiated, it should be added to the list of breaches of Eire neutrality which he was preparing.
The War Cabinet
(1) took note of the above statement;
(2) agreed to invite the attention of the Secretary of State for
Dominion Affairs to the report of a German submarine in Donegal Bay with a view to the suggested action, as 0j&a recorded above, being taken.

This would support General Gamelin's theory that an attack on the Maginot Line was probable, although it might well be that the reason for this concentration was fear of a French attack.

German Allegation of the Sinking of H.M. Aircraft-Carrier
Ark Royal.
6. Arising out of the discussion recorded in Minute 5 above, the First Lord of the Admiralty said that, as regards the German allegation that His Majesty's Aircraft-Carrier Ark Royal had been sunk, the position was as follows :
(i) The United States Naval Attache" was with the Fleet, and had thus seen H.M.S. Ark Royal since the date on which it was alleged by the Germans that she had been sunk.
(ii) Full particulars regarding the recent air attack on the Fleet had been sent by the Admiralty to our Naval Attache in Rome for the confidential information of the Chief of the Italian Naval Staff.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.

Anglo-Soviet Trade
Negotiations.
Position of British Ships at Archangel and Murmansk. (Previous Bef erence: W.M. (39) 32nd Conclusions, Minute 15.)
9. The First Lord of the Admiralty said that he was increasingly^ anxious regarding the position of the British ships at Archangel and Murmansk and their crews. From the latest report it appeared that, while these ships were not as yet formally detained by the Soviet authorities, it was the intention of those authorities not to permit them to sail until payment had been made by the British importers either in United States dollars or in Swedish kroner, and also until certain machinery now in this country had been delivered.
Sir Orme Sargent agreed that the position was serious, and referred to telegram No. 340, dated the 29th September, 1939, from His Majesty's Ambassador, Moscow, stating that he had entirely failed in his efforts to communicate with the ships in question, and that he considered that the Soviet obstruction in this matter was highly suspicious. He (Sir Orme Sargent) had no information regarding the progress of the negotiations in this matter now being undertaken by the Minister of Supply.
266
The War Cabinet agreed
That, in view of the urgent need for securing assurances that neither the British ships at Archangel and Murmansk nor their crews should be interfered with, arrangements should be made for the War Cabinet to be informed at the meeting to be held the following day (Monday, the 2nd October, 1939) of the stage reached by the Minister of Supply in his negotiations with the Soviet Trade Commissioner in connection with the proposed exchange of rubber and tin for Soviet timber.
Richmond Terrace, S.W. 1, October 1, 1939.
